body:
I think that will in turn fail on sanity's check_submodules.

On Aug 3, 2017 8:30 PM, "Matt Kwong" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

*@matt-kwong* commented on this pull request.
------------------------------

In tools/internal_ci/linux/grpc_build_submodule_at_head.sh
<https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/12048#discussion_r131224381>:

> +# limitations under the License.
+
+# Build portability tests with an updated submodule
+
+set -ex
+
+# change to grpc repo root
+cd $(dirname $0)/../../..
+
+source tools/internal_ci/helper_scripts/prepare_build_linux_rc
+
+# Update submodule and commit it so changes are passed to Docker
+(cd third_party/$RUN_TESTS_FLAGS && git pull origin master)
+git -c user.name='foo' -c user.email='foo@google.com' commit -a -m
'Update submodule'
+
+tools/run_tests/run_tests_matrix.py -f portability linux
--internal_ci --build_only

Good point, I think removing portability from the -f argument fixes that.

â€”

.

> I think that will in turn fail on sanity's check_submodules.

It's build only, so that test shouldn't be run. Nico believes we should be able to catch most potential failures in the build steps, but we can switch to actually running the tests if we fail to catch futures issues with build only.
